"It should be noted that the PUBLIC HEALTH (COVID-19 EMERGENCY POWERS) REGULATIONS 2020 (as  amended) prohibits any person from assembling in a group of more than 75 persons for any reason in  any public or private place. The regulations also prohibit any person from hosting a group of more than  75 persons for any reason in any public or private place. However the Minister of National Security may  grant an exemption (a âlarge group exemptionâ) permitting a group of more than 75 persons to  assemble.  If you are planning to organize an event where more than 75 people will be assembling you should firstly  apply to the Minister of National Security for an exemption.  If you are planning to organize an event where people from different households will assemble â  whether or not the total number is less or more than 75, you should follow this guidance. Please  remember that we are still in the midst of a public health pandemic"    https://web.archive.org/web/20200916170633/https://www.gov.bm/sites/default/files/COVID-19%20Guidance%20for%20Events%20and%20Gatherings%20for%20Website%20200908.pdf

"Visitors must present a copy of the pre-departure PCR COVID-19 negative test result to health officers on request and a copy of the Travel Authorization form.  Travelers arriving at the airport will undergo a mandatory non-contact temperature check.  Residents and visitors will undergo PCR COVID-19 testing at the L.F. Wade International Airport and quarantine at home or in their room at their accommodation until results are ready (turnaround time is approximately 24 hours in most cases, though results may take longer depending on arrival time). This applies to adults and children ages 10 and up. Children less than 10 years old are exempt from the PCR COVID-19 test.  Residents (including work permit holders) who do not have a pre-departure negative PCR COVID-19 test result must quarantine for eight days after arrival. They will not be tested on day four, but they will be tested on day eight and will be released from quarantine with a day eight negative results. If you did take an RT-PCR COVID-19 test before departure and receive a negative result during your first four days in Bermuda, you will be released from quarantine. You will still have to test on day 4, day 8, and day 14.  The location and time of each of your tests will automatically be booked for you, so please do not book separate appointments. You will receive email reminders 24 hours before each test.  Wear a face mask and practice physical distancing to the greatest extent possible."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200916170209/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/

From the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities:    "Thanks to the CARES Act enacted in March, 30 million unemployed workers claimed unemployment benefits in the week ending May 16 that were more generous than they normally would have received, including nearly 11 million who would have received no benefits at all.[1] If policymakers donât act to extend them, however, the CARES Actâs boost in benefit levels will expire on July 31 and its eligibility expansions and additional weeks of benefits will expire on December 31, while the support unemployed workers and the economy need will remain substantial."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200904191822/https://www.cbpp.org/research/federal-budget/cares-act-measures-strengthening-unemployment-insurance-should-continue    However, the CARES act additional benefits are being debated over and not yet implemented, so there may also be an argument for coding a 0 from July 31 as while Trump's most recent announcement will eventually cover claims from August, the policy had been announced but does not seem implemented since previous benefits expired July 31.    "A $600-a-week federal supplement to unemployment benefits, enacted to address the pandemic, stopped at the end of July. That has pulled away a key source of support, not just for the nearly 30 million Americans receiving benefits but also for the broader economy.    âThe status of the financial relief is a huge question mark hanging over the economy,â said Daniel Zhao, senior economist for the career site Glassdoor.    Mr. Trump said Saturday that he was taking executive action to provide unemployed workers with $400 a week in extra payments, on top of their regular state jobless benefits. He did so after talks on a new round of pandemic relief stalled in Congress.    The Senate adjourned on Thursday until early September, and House members had already left Washington. The departures all but end any chance of a quick agreement on sending stimulus checks to American taxpayers, reviving lapsed unemployment benefits and providing billions of dollars for schools, testing, child care, small businesses, and state and local governments.    In the meantime, states are scrambling to figure out how to carry out Mr. Trumpâs plan, with unemployed workers wondering whether the money will arrive in time to prevent lasting financial harm."    Timeline of implementation is also not clear:    "Even for those who qualify, it could be weeks or even months before they begin receiving any extra money. States will need to adjust to the new provisions when they are already overwhelmed by unemployment filings."    "The program is retroactive to Aug. 1, meaning that workers should eventually receive payments for all of August.    But Mr. Trumpâs executive action caps spending on the program at $44 billion, enough to cover five or six weeks of benefits, assuming all states sign up. That means the program could end almost as soon as it begins.    It is still possible that Congress could either revive the original unemployment supplement â though probably at less than $600 a week â or appropriate more money for Mr. Trumpâs replacement."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200831044139/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/08/13/business/economy/unemployment-benefits-coronavirus.html
Student loan reprieve lasts until September 30.    summary:  http://archive.fo/cZQtI

Targeted closings remain in effect in several states according to the Edweek tracker. These include Hawaii, California, Oregon, New Mexico, and West Virginia. Some US territories (Washington DC, Puerto Rico) continue with full closures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200928032026/https://www.edweek.org/ew/section/multimedia/map-covid-19-schools-open-closed.html?s_kwcid=AL%216416%213%21455874877102%21b%21%21g%21%21school%2520closures&gclid=CjwKCAjw8MD7BRArEiwAGZsrBRfHqJRiG8pqlV9u1Fcw4A23jNB5VKo7BPMWpvm75kV5qbWYLn_G7RoC808QAvD_BwE

NYT tracker shows retail, restaurants, gyms and hair salons still closed in some states (ex: WA, NY, CA)  https://web.archive.org/web/20200926173926/https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/states-reopen-map-coronavirus.html
Some event venues are being reopened; however, events proceed at reduced capacity in several states (e.g. Pennsylvania).  https://web.archive.org/web/20200928032339if_/https://www.washingtonpost.com/

There do not appear to be any regions of the country that continue to enforce a gathering limit of under 10 people. Some states, such as Kansas, enforce a limit of 15, with others limiting at 25.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200928032339if_/https://www.washingtonpost.com/
Public transit systems throughout the country are open but often operate with restrictions.
No evidence of stay-at-home requirements in effect. Recommendations continue to advise limiting movements.

States like New York continue to require visitors from other states with high caseloads to quarantine upon arrival.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200926214403/https://coronavirus.health.ny.gov/covid-19-travel-advisory
The United States continues to prevent arrivals from certain countries. https://web.archive.org/web/20200928033806/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html

Per the previous coding, CARES funding is expiring in many sectors.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200928035352/https://thehill.com/policy/finance/518370-households-businesses-fall-into-financial-holes-as-covid-aid-dries-up  Its replacement, a $300-400 unemployment benefits cheque under the "Lost Wages Assistance" program, continues to be disbursed in some states, as per one tracker.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200926111345/https://www.unemploymentpua.com/articles/lwatracker.html
Student loan reprieve continues.
